title: Monday, 8th October 2018
bodyHTML:
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Sheesh.

VV75 morning
chopper bear 11.22 new record
VV75 monday eh?
rw42 Morning!
BE11:23am

Welcome to Markets Live, the daily chronicling of our attempts to make this Rube Goldberg machine work.

Badger Talk about making an entrance...
Deep Breath everyone... SNAFU with bells!
BE11:24am

Had you tried to log on 20 minutes ago you'd have seen this.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

VV75 my bookmark still says that
Blank canvas greetings all
BE11:24am

Which was, apparently, because the AWS keys were rotated.

Plato the Cook So you have a turnkey system
Deep Breath everyone... The old AWS rotation issue. Thought so.
BE11:25am

Anyway, we're here. I don't think any readers are but frankly, no loss.

11:25 am
undefined
Finlay Was worried about you all for a moment there..
Soundbuy Morning -
BE11:26am

Okay, so now we're alone, what should we do to pass the time?

Binocular still in a job?
madrugada Most readers have probably given up.
lonrho jefferies downgrade on vodafone
BE11:28am

Day two on the Bloomberg phantom chip thing, maybe? Weekend press was interesting.

Soundbuy Repetitive strain injury forom F5 this am. Can I sue?
VV75 Aston Martin is not only a costly car..
Electric Dragon That's Numberwang! Let's rotate the board!
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Starting with Buzzfeed: https://www.buzzfe...-servers-spies-fbi

BE11:28am

A senior security engineer directly involved in Apple’s internal investigation described it as “endoscopic,” noting they had never seen a chip like the one described in the story, let alone found one. “I don’t know if something like this even exists,” this person said, noting that Apple was not provided with a malicious chip or motherboard to examine. “We were given nothing. No hardware. No chips. No emails.”

littleclenches put up shut up time for RPC today at 5pm
BE11:30am

Journalists often get accused of making up their anonymous quotes, or at least punching them up a bit for the sake of the copy. But no journalist in the world would dare to fictionalise a source describing an investigation as "endoscopic".

Soundbuy Aye, RPC off 8% ish.............hmmmm
11:31 am
BE11:31am

We also have El Reg. https://www.thereg...s_uk_intelligence/

hedgehog rpc trading stment delayed
BE11:32am

Infosec pros have also started criticizing Bloomberg for the lack of hard data and technical information to support the story, beyond its 17 anonymous sources. One particularly annoying thing is that the graphics used in the blockbuster article – depicting the spy chip and its placement on the board – look to be purely illustrative, making it difficult to verify the claims or even check if a server motherboard has one of Beijing's bugs.

Excel Developer Hello
BE11:33am

Yeah, that is indeed irritating. It was pointed out within a few minutes of publication that the chip in the picture didn't look awfully like a signal conditioner, which it was supposed to .....

rwl @Electric Dragon - I miss Numberwang :)
11:34 am
BE11:34am

.... but then, the chip in the picture was apparently a representation the next generation one, which the story pretty much said existed only in rumour, rather than the one what was allegedly found, though we're still unclear by whom.

BE11:36am

The Bloomberg Way, the stylebook all reporters had to treat as the equivalent of an L Ron Hubbard, defines something called the Aunt Agatha test. In short, if your Aunt Agatha won't understand it, don't put it in copy.

BE11:37am

That's quite restrictive when dealing with highly technical stuff, as everyone's Aunt Agatha has a different understanding of PCBs.

alewis2005 @soundbuy I take it you weren't trying to get glastonbury tickets yesterday then... that was a proper f5-fest
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Anyway, enough about them. Back to us.

undefined
BE11:37am

So ............. First things first ............

Otter Hello internet friends
11:37 am
RPC Group PLC (RPC:LSE): Last: 755.00, down 58.6 (-7.20%), High: 813.60, Low: 734.00, Volume: 796.81k
BE11:38am

The website claimed there was a trading update due today.

tadam RPC has confirmed that trading update is today (as per Bloomber).
BE11:38am

Which we're told we should still expect at some point.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

But you also have the PUSU over the two bidders due to expire at 5pm.

DJ Fevertree off almost 25% now from highs..
BE11:40am

Now .... It seems there's not a whole lot of confidence around about the bid talks leading to an actual bid.

Soundbuy @ alewis2005 - any joy?
BE11:41am

Psquared Asset Management, a Swiss hedgie, was raising its bets against RPC quite aggressively last week.

alewis2005 yeah we got 36. Unfortunately there were 54 of us though...
Soundbuy :)
11:42 am
BE11:42am

But of course, if a company has price sensitive information it has a duty to release it to the market asap. That relates both to trading and to the potential bids.

alewis2005 I'm in the lucky 36 :)
BE11:43am

Therefore, we've no option but to wait for RPC to fulfil it's duty.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

On Vodafone, mentioned somewhere back there: it's the divi.

BE11:43am

Jefferies saying they have to cut big.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 156.36, down 3.86 (-2.41%), High: 159.62, Low: 156.22, Volume: 21.76m
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Dividend policy dates back to FY12 when FCF was enhanced by VZW receipts. Nearly 5Y after exiting the US, dividend cover still hinges on FCF growth. But VOD is structurally squeezed. It is nether the national champion FTTP-deployer nor pay TV leader nor remedy-taking challenger. LBTY deal elevates leverage for modest value accretion, requiring a 40% DPS cut to delever to 2.5x by Mar23. Tower sales would not turn us positive. Political support for 5G invt might.

Soundbuy @DJ - I had a dabble there this am. ...........a wee horse racing punt sized trade to amuse............
BE11:45am

Acquiring LBTY German/CEE assets will lever VOD to 3.3x p/f Mar19 incl hybrids/MCBs. On current dividend policy, leverage will still be 3.0x by Mar23. A small DPS cut has little impact on leverage. But the need to focus on debt reduction means that even a large DPS cut will not free up resources to invest more into projects that might enhance earnings growth organically.

BE11:46am

None of which is particularly new, in terms of ideas. Vodafone's been a prisoner of its payout ratio forever.

TonaldDrump @alewis2005 you've managed to get 36 glasto tickets?
alewis2005 yeah
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Jerry Dellis adds in some cynicism about the flogging off of the towers, saying "no silver bullet" to debt.

BE11:47am

(1) Replacing financial debt with ongoing service fee obligations will not materially alter rating agency assessments of leverage. (2) Outsourcing towers does not create value since VOD's credit rating should translate into long-run funding costs well below those an independent tower operator would need to build into service fees over time, and VOD already exploits passive site sharing with rival operators. (3) There is a potential loss of n/w advantage from allowing challenger rivals access to strategic sites. Any attempt by VOD to contractually constrain who an acquiring tower operator can lease capacity to would surely store up anti-trust risk.

undefined
TonaldDrump to resell?
11:50 am
BE11:50am

Hey, I'm so glad we did an emergency reboot of the servers to get this running so you could have a forum to talk about your Glastonbury tickets.

BE11:50am

Meanwhile, on this side of the page ......

chad_john anything on the frocking news at French Connection?
BE11:51am

Lancashire profit warning. Similar story to RSA, in that marine and big catastrophe are causing problems.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

What this likely means is no special div.

Lancashire Holdings Ltd (LRE:LSE): Last: 554.52, down 32.48 (-5.53%), High: 570.00, Low: 505.00, Volume: 611.80k
BE11:52am

As well as a barely profitable year, assuming the losses are at the top end of the $55m-$75m estimate.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:53am

In 2017 Lancashire has skipped special dividend after recording a US$71m loss for the year that saw US$182m of nat cat losses. While the company remains well capitalized with US$1.48m of statutory capital as of 1H18, we believe that in the light of 3Q18 losses its ability to distribute substantial special dividends will be reduced – since 2008 this is only the fourth quarterly loss (3Q of 2008, 3Q and 4Q of 2017), and Lancashire did not pay a special dividend in either of these years. Prior to the profit warning we’ve modeled FY18 dividend of US$104.4m, including a US$84.2m special (US$0.42/share).

BE11:53am

In our view, industry peers will also likely see increased nat cat/man made losses during the quarter, although not of the 2017 magnitude. According to RMS, both hurricane Florence and typhoon Jebi may cost the insurance industry US$3-5bn each, typhoon Mangkhut may cost US$1-2bn (AIR estimate), with damage from typhoon Trami comparable in size. Both large European reinsurers (Munich Re, Swiss Re, Hannover Re) and London Market player (i.e. Hiscox) are likely to see elevated large losses in line with or in excess of the budget.

Soundbuy Lancashire Holdings - wasn't that an M&A fave a couple of yr s back when no- life was all the rage.........
11:53 am
Hiscox Ltd (HSX:LSE): Last: 1,674, down 31 (-1.82%), High: 1,695, Low: 1,665, Volume: 524.24k
BE11:54am

Otherwise in the sector, Investec downgrade of Hastings.

alewis2005 no not to resell - glasto have got that locked down, thankfully. We've got a group of 54 people who all want to go so we all f5-ed as hard as we could and manged to get tickets for 36 of us.
BE11:55am

Reduce from add.

11:54 am
Hastings Group Holdings PLC (HSTG:LSE): Last: 237.20, down 10.8 (-4.35%), High: 245.00, Low: 236.40, Volume: 326.26k
Excel Developer China Shares Down ~4% despite China Central Bank cutting reserve requirements over the weekend!
Soundbuy Cranswick off 5.5%................any notes this am?
BE11:55am

More competitive auto market, and Hastings' need to grow means it has to take a hit on underwriting margins, they say.

undefined
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Okay, what else?

gunner123 What do we think about UK RE from here? Goldman liking very little
Excel Developer @BE: China!
BE11:57am

Fevertree mentioned earlier.

Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 3,105, down 117 (-3.63%), High: 3,301, Low: 3,057, Volume: 492.22k
chopper bear french connection ?
sprout @ excel - China markets were shut last week for autumn festival, so most of that is them catching up with global market risk off last week.
11:59 am
BE11:59am

You'll all know what we reported earlier in the year and there's nothing more to say there. In terms of the subsequent retreat -- well, there might have been some short-term money that was exiting .... But from a more fundamental tack ......

BE11:59am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:59am

What's New? UK Nielsen data published on 5 October points to a slowdown in Fever Tree growth from 75.2% growth in the 4W to 12/08/18 to 37.7% in the 4W to 09/09/18. Note that the UK accounts for c52% of group sales. See p.2 for further details

Is Nielsen a reliable indicator of growth? According to Nielsen, 2H16 Fever-Tree growth in the UK was 126% vs Fever-Tree's reported 124%. 1H17 growth per Nielsen was 139% vs Fever-Tree's reported 113% and 2H17 Nielsen 119% vs the company reporting 87%. For 1H18, UK growth per Nielsen was 86% vs Fever Tree's reported 73%. Therefore, while off-trade is only c.50% of Fever- Tree's UK sales, Nielsen data is not a bad indicator of growth in the UK.

Excel Developer @sprout: ah cheers for that.
alewis2005 Any comment on the latest Brewdog fund raise? It's closing in the next couple of weeks
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

sprout although HSCEI was weak today (HK's been open mostly), so true that RRR cut hasn't exactly reversed the declines.
BE12:00pm

However ..........

Excel Developer ta
BE12:01pm

Should this be a cause for concern? We do not dismiss the moderation in Fever-Tree's UK rate of growth per Nielsen altogether, and we do expect UK growth to slow as the base becomes larger, the slower data point should be seen in the context of an overall CSD category that has slowed from 31.5% to 10.3% during the 4W to 09/09/18. We believe that the moderation in the rate of growth of the overall CSD category could be attributable to a degree of normalisation after a particularly warm July (4W to 14/07/18 +21.5%) and August (4W to 12/08/18 +31.5%). We believe that other considerations could include the timing of in-store promotions and other retailer activities. Therefore, viewed within the context of an overall CSD category that has slowed by 2/3 in 4W to 09/09/18 we do not view Fever's slowdown (growth slowed by 1/2) as representing the beginning of a material slowdown in UK growth.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

What does this mean for our numbers? For 2H18, we assume 20% growth in UK. For 2H YTD, growth is running at 62%. If growth carries on at the current rate of 37.7%, then growth would be close to 50% in 2H.

Soundbuy Was there a Bernstein note re FEVR this am?
BE12:02pm

Our assumptions for the US are also far from aggressive at only 17% for 2H.

BE12:02pm

Therefore we see limited risk to our overall group expectation of 22% growth for 2H.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

They're buyers because it's "a unique asset that offers a leveraged
play on premiumisation trends in spirits in a sub-category where there is a disconnect between premium spirits and mixers."

BE12:04pm

(@Soundbuy: that was Friday. Also a buy.)

Soundbuy Ah............ta
undefined
DJ @Soundbuy thought that was Berenberg?
Roidster hello all
Soundbuy @DJ - think you're right.....
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

French Connection ..... Putting itself up for sale ..........

BE12:06pm

(@Soundbuy/DG, yes, Berenberg. Not the other lot.)

BE12:07pm

Stephen Marks looking for an exit.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

First question is how you value French Connection, given it's in retrenchment mode and lost £5.5m in the first half.

alewis2005 FC has been in turnaround mode for fricking years
BE12:08pm

Management aim to reach profitability in the current year.

BE12:09pm

But they're doing it by closing lossmaking stores, including 40 in the past five years. It only has 39 left, which will fall to 30 in the medium term.

12:10 pm
French Connection Group PLC (FCCN:LSE): Last: 55.50, up 12.6 (+29.36%), High: 62.00, Low: 47.20, Volume: 349.34k
BE12:11pm

Wo ........ let's assume breakeven this year and subtract the £18m of cash on the balance sheet.

Tsetse Didn't someone already kick the tires on FC and walk away a little while back?
BE12:13pm

Put retail at zero, stick £14.2m of wholesale EBIT and the £6.4m of licencing on a multiple of, what, 3x maybe? And you get a price in the £70m region.

12:14 pm
BE12:14pm

That's my back-of-the-envelope maths, to be clear.

BE12:15pm

Difficult to identify a buyer here, even if Marks is a motivated seller.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today.
BE12:16pm

Anyway, that's all just my waffle. Don't have any sellside on it because, I'd assume, Numis etc have gone restricted.

12:17 pm
BE12:17pm

Here's Numis's forecasts. Do your own maths.

BE12:17pm

undefined
Soundbuy Cheers all
VV75 thanks
12:18 pm
BE12:18pm

Cranswick, sorry, not sure beyond there being a big seller around at the open.

Cranswick PLC (CWK:LSE): Last: 3,190, down 184 (-5.45%), High: 3,360, Low: 3,158, Volume: 77.82k
Soundbuy Ta
BE12:20pm

And if you want a few extra bits on Spire and Norsk, go here: https://www.ft.com...-b276-b9069bde0956

12:20 pm
BE12:20pm

Apologies for the late start. And the late finish.

BE12:20pm

We'll be back tomorrow, technology allowing.

BE12:21pm

Afternoon all.
